column2: CHAPTER I. A SPY'S DUTY
column3: CHAPTER one A SPY'S DUTY

column2: I am not without self-control, yet when Miss Davies entered the room with that air of importance she invariably assumes when she has an unusually fine position to offer, I could not hide all traces of my anxiety.

column2: She has passed me by--my heart goes down, down--when suddenly her look returns and she singles me out.

column2: Miss Saunders. Then, "I have a word to say to you."

column2: There is a rustle about me; five disappointed girls sink back into their seats as I quickly rise and follow Miss Davies out.

column2: In the hall she faced me with these words:

column2: You are discreet, and you evidently desire a position.	You are discreet, and you evidently desire a position.

column2: You will find a gentleman in my sitting-room.
column3: You will find a gentleman in my sitting room.

column2: If you come to terms with him, well and good.
column3: If you come to terms with him, well and good.

column2: If not, I shall expect you to forget all about him and his errand the moment you leave his presence.
column3: If not, I shall expect you to forget all about him and his errand the moment you leave his presence.

column2: You understand me?"

column3: I am not to talk whatever the outcome.

column2: This position--involving secrecy--is it one you would advise me to take, even if I did not stand in need of it so badly?

column2: It is a first-class opportunity for a young woman as experienced as yourself."

column2: A gentleman standing at one of the windows turned quickly at the sound of my step and came forward.

column2: Instantly whatever doubt I may have felt concerning the nature of the work about to be proposed to me yielded to the certainty that, however much it might involve of the strange and difficult, the man whose mission it was to seek my aid was one to inspire confidence and respect.

column2: A man to sway women and also quite capable of moving men (this was evident at a glance); but a man under a cloud just at present,--a very heavy cloud which both irked and perplexed him.
column3: A man to sway women and also quite capable of moving men (this was evident at a glance); but a man under a cloud just at present,--a very heavy cloud which both irked and perplexed him.

column2: Did I impress him as favorably as he did me?

column2: A look of relief, so vivid that it startled me, altered at once the whole character of his countenance; and perceiving how intense was the power and fascination underlying his quiet exterior, I asked myself who and what this man was; no ordinary personage, I was sure, but who?

column2: The case is not a common one, or, rather,--he caught himself up quickly, "the circumstances are not.

column2: My wife is well, but--she is not happy.

column2: She is very unhappy, deeply, unaccountably so, and I do not know why."
column3: She is very unhappy, deeply, unaccountably so, and I do not know why."

column2: It would make a new man of me."

column2: The meaning, the deep meaning in his tone, if not in the adjuration itself, was undeniable; but my old habit of self-control stood me in good stead and I remained silent and watchful, weighing every look and word.
column3: The meaning, the deep meaning in his tone, if not in the adjuration itself, was undeniable; but my old habit of self control stood me in good stead and I remained silent and watchful, weighing every look and word.

column2: A week ago she was the lightest hearted woman in town,--the happiest wife, the merriest mother.	A week ago she was the lightest hearted woman in town,--the happiest wife, the merriest mother.

column2: To-day she is a mere wreck of her former self, pallid, drawn, almost speechless, yet she is not ill.
column3: To day she is a mere wreck of her former self, pallid, drawn, almost speechless, yet she is not ill.

column2: She will not acknowledge to an ache or a pain; will not even admit that any change has taken place in her.

column2: And I am as ignorant of the cause of it all--as you are!" he burst out.
column3: And I am as ignorant of the cause of it all-as you are!" he burst out.

column3: He says there is something serious the matter with her, but he can not help her, as it is not in any respect physical, and advises me to find out what is on her mind.

column2: As if that had not been my first care!

column2: They see the difference in her, but can not tell the cause. And I am obliged to go away and leave her in this state.

column2: Miss Davies has not told me your name, I made bold to interpolate.

column2: He stared, shook himself together, and quietly, remarked:
column3: He stared, shook himself together, and quietly, remarked:

column2: I am Henry Packard.
column3: I am Henry Packard.

column2: The city's mayor! and not only that, the running candidate for governor. I knew him well by name, even if I did not know, or rather had not recognized his face.
column3: The city's mayor! and not only that, the running candidate for governor. I knew him well by name, even if I did not know, or rather had not recognized his face.

column2: I beg pardon, I somewhat tremulously began, but he waved the coming apology aside as easily, as he had my first attempt at ingratiation. In fact, he appeared to be impatient of every unnecessary word.
column3: I beg pardon, I somewhat tremulously began, but he waved the coming apology aside as easily, as he had my first attempt at ingratiation. In fact, he appeared to be impatient of every unnecessary word.

column2: This I could, in a dim sort of way, understand.

column2: He was at the crisis of his fate, and so was his party.
column3: He was at the crisis of his fate, and so was his party.

column2: For several years a struggle had gone on between the two nearly matched elements in this western city, which, so far, had resulted in securing him two terms of office--possibly because his character appealed to men of all grades and varying convictions.
column3: For several years a struggle had gone on between the two nearly matched elements in this western city, which, so far, had resulted in securing him two terms of office-possibly because his character appealed to men of all grades and varying convictions.

column2: But the opposite party was strong in the state, and the question whether he could carry his ticket against such odds, and thus give hope to his party in the coming presidential election, was one yet to be tested. Forceful as a speaker, he was expected to reap hundreds of votes from the mixed elements that invariably thronged to hear him, and, ignorant as I necessarily was of the exigencies of such a campaign, I knew that not only his own ambition, but the hopes of his party, depended on the speeches he had been booked to make in all parts of the state.
column3: But the opposite party was strong in the state, and the question whether he could carry his ticket against such odds, and thus give hope to his party in the coming presidential election, was one yet to be tested.
